user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_nonce_timestamp:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function get_nonce_timestamp:
#define MHD_MD5_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define NONCE_STD_LEN(digest_size) ((digest_size)*2+TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN)
...
#define MD5_DIGEST_SIZE (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*MD5_BYTES_IN_WORD)
...
#define SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE
...
#define TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN (TIMESTAMP_BIN_SIZE*2)
...
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                       size_t maxlen,
                       uint64_t *out_val)
{
  size_t i;
  uint64_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT64_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 16)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 16;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  }

  if (i)
    *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: With the supplied macro definitions (MHD_MD5_SUPPORT, MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT or MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT defined), the controlling expression depends on the runtime parameter noncelen and is not invariant, so Rule 14.3 is NOT violated. However, if all those feature macros are absent (so the preprocessor removes the && comparisons) the condition reduces to literal 'if (true)' which is an invariant controlling expression and would violate Rule 14.3 (no exception applies).
